question_title: Who gets to decide what's an extraordinary claim? [SEP] question_content: If extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence, who gets to decide which claims are ordinary and which are extraordinary? [SEP] best_answer: Well. pretty much as a rule, the whole of humanity decides what's ordinary and what isn't. Technically if you want it written in stone you'll have to do a world-wide poll, including every living person. That's not really feasible, though.\n\nEdit: I disagree. You have to be reasonable, you can't expect everything to be perfect, you really can't. You have to declare something sensibly "ordinary" or "extraordinary" and realise that no matter what there's always going to be those few  who are going to disagree, no matter what. By the standard of perfect, everything is "meaningless" because nothing is perfect.

question_title: What is the meaning of  'secular humanism'? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: secular humanism
n.
An outlook or philosophy that advocates human rather than religious values.

Secular humanism is an active lifestance that holds a naturalisic worldview and advocates the use of reason, compassion, scientific inquiry, ethics, justice and equality.

"Secular humanism" is distinguished from the broader "humanism" in that the secular Humanist prefers free inquiry over dogma wisdom—upholding the scientific method for inquiry, while rejecting "revealed knowledge" and theistic morality, though not necessarily faith. Secular humanism has appeal to athiests, agnostics, freethinkers, rationalists, skeptics, and materialists. Its basic tenets may be simplified as:

Humans have value and can solve human problems 
Science, free speech, rational thought, democracy, and freedom in the arts go together 
There is nothing supernatural

question_title: For a group project? [SEP] question_content: What are some things different countries/cultures share in common?
So far I have sports, music, food and parenting.  Any ideas you have are welcome.  Thanks [SEP] best_answer: Religion.

We may all worship God differently, but we all have the same goal in mind and that is to worship God.  The church I was raised in teaches that Jesus is the son of God, while other religions believe he was a prophet.  Some believe Mary, being the mother of Jesus more important than others.  Some religions honor the day Jesus was born while others pay more attention to his death and resurrection.

But all of us believe in God.

question_title: One stupid question? [SEP] question_content: If something is 
"total price of the item including discount " does that mean that it includes the discount, or that the discount has been  subtracted? [SEP] best_answer: In accounting, the discount would be written with a minus sign in fron of it, meaning that the discount is negative, because it is designed to reduce the price.  With me so far?  When you add all the numbers together, the negative ones do not add but actually subtract.  Simple rules of arithmetics.  Plus (+) and minus (-) become minus (-), minus (-) and minus (-) become plus.  

But generally, whenever someone says something is included, think of it that whatever action had to be taken, was already taken with respect to that item.

The simple truth? denominations are proof of deceitful men drawing men to follow themselves, thus putting a stumbling block in the path of weak minded persons to full of apathy as regards their own wish for eternal life.

question_title: what is the controversy about The Da Vinci Code all About ? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Ok, the book is about a 2000 year old secret that the church hid.  The secret is that Jesus was Married to Marry Magdaline, and the church made her out to be a prostitute to slander her image.  The book (and thereby the movie) is fiction, but it's based on the claims and theories of prominant historians and Biblical scholars.  The story gives you some interesting food for thought.  The reason that it's so contraversial is Christians find the whole idea of Jesus being a sexual person with a wife and children appalling, yet they can't disprove the claims.  The claims and theories may be true or they may be false, but the idea that the church has been lying for nearly 2000 years frightens some people and outrages others.  'If the church was lying about that,' they think 'what else could they have lied about?'  This frighten's the church authority.  If people stop beliving in the authority of the church, many church authorities will soon be out of a job.  Others belive that without a church authority to look up to, people will begin behaving like animals.  Most people just look at it as a great book (movie) with topics that may or may not be true.

question_title: Why is China so heavily populated? [SEP] question_content: Why do they have so many kids in such a small country? It's kinda sad! [SEP] best_answer: Before there was birth control, it was normal when you had lots of children (5,7,9,10...). But in the previous century the Chinese government introduced birth control because there were getting too much Chinese: you couldn't get more then one child. For each child "extra" you have to pay more taxes.

question_title: Which is correct? [SEP] question_content: One: How long after you date a man, he is allowed to kiss you.
Two: After How long you date a man, he is allowed to kiss you. [SEP] best_answer: The clause "how long after you date a man" is the correct one, however, as several people pointed out, the second part should be in question form: "is he allowed to kiss you?"

However, at least according to dating behaviour in my culture (I'm Canadian, Catholic but not especially religious--I've also been with my husband for years), it doesn't make much sense. The question implies that you and the man have one date, and then at some point after that one date (the question is asking how long after) he is allowed to kiss you. Presumably the idea is really: "How long after you start dating a man".

Now, if you are the one doing the allowing (as opposed to, for example, your parents or a chaperone), it would be better to ask "do you allow him to kiss you?"--but again, that may depend on your culture.

So in the end: How long after you start dating a man, is he allowed to kiss you?

Or else: How long after you start dating a man, do you allow him to kiss you?

question_title: Where would we be without stupid people? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Stupid people have long been a part of society and will continue to be so until human engineering erases stupidity from the human genome (unlikely anytime soon).  So, without stupid people, the world would be a much more boring place.  For example, there would be much fewer funny videos on the internet without stupid people.  Furthermore, we would not have such a diverse society in the United States without stupid people.  Finally, and perhaps most importantly, without stupid people, it would be close to impossible for anyone to get into a good college.

question_title: Okay I have a pretty common phone number and I keep on getting wrong calls...what to do Im tired of it!!? [SEP] question_content: Okay beside blocking the people that keeps on calling for about 15 differents person about 2 time each a day here at my house...Those are my usuals....is their a way to tell them to be more vigilant when dialing that can actually marked them to the point they will be ....or do the phone compagny charges to block some phone numbers....??? [SEP] best_answer: Respond as if you were the person they are looking for. If your number is mistaken for a pizza delivery number, then take their order, and, of course, never deliver it. If they call you again for their pizza, tell them they have the wrong number.\n\nOr if your number is mistaken for a home number, and they ask to talk with someone, say that person is not at home but you can take the message for them. When they spend hours waiting for the person to call back, they'll learn they had the wrong number.

question_title: Will he think I am a crazy girl? [SEP] question_content: He was 29, I was 16. My mom found out and turned him in. It has been 15 yrs. and when I see him in public he looks like he wants to talk to me or he would like to run for his life. I am not sure which. I wrote him a letter apologizing for any grief that I have caused him in his life. I sent it via his brother, he is married now and I do not want to cause problems there. I left no return address or phone number. I am not looking to speak to him, I just needed some closure. [SEP] best_answer: What, did he rape you? If not, who cares? 16 year olds don't look much different than 18 year olds, it's a little wierd but not pedo. In some places (yes, even in this country, I believe) it's legal to have sex at 16. If he didn't rape you and you were a willing participant in laying the guy, it's your mom that caused him grief. 

He might still have a love for you, just afraid. He might not think you're crazy or any such thing, and he might even send something back. As long as his wife doesn't find the letter, he should be fine.

By the way, why did your mom bother to have him arrested? I would have just let it lie. It was probably a bunch of stress and trouble for no reason. Ah well. Good luck, girl.

question_title: Before eating of the Tree of Knowledge of Good and Evil, A&E didn't know the difference, so how could they sin [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Every human person is endowed with a spiritual soul, with intellect and with free will. Man is rational and therefore like God; he is created with free will and is master over his acts. 

God created man in his image and established him in his friendship. A spiritual creature, man can live this friendship only in free submission to God. The prohibition against eating "of the tree of the knowledge of good and evil" spells this out: "for in the day that you eat of it, you shall die." The "tree of the knowledge of good and evil" symbolically evokes the insurmountable limits that man, being a creature, must freely recognize and respect with trust. Man is dependent on his Creator, and subject to the laws of creation and to the moral norms that govern the use of freedom. 

Although set by God in a state of rectitude man, enticed by the evil one, abused his freedom at the very start of history. Man, tempted by the devil, let his trust in his Creator die in his heart and, abusing his freedom, disobeyed God's command. He lifted himself up against God, and sought to attain his goal apart from him. By his sin Adam, as the first man, lost the original holiness and justice he had received from God, not only for himself but for all human beings.

question_title: Why is there less racism in other countries than   in the United States ? [SEP] question_content: People in Europe seem to enjoy every gift of life. [SEP] best_answer: What makes you think that?  In France, the streets are full of protesters who think that the French laws discriminate against arabs, and other foreigners.  The fact that the US confronts it's racism, even imperfectly, is better than the French hiding their collective heads in the sand.
And, have you ever observed how black are received, and treated, in Germany?

Travel in europe, and if you get away from the tourist traps, you will see that there is greater racism and predjudice in Europe, against Albanians, Serbs, africans, and anyone who is not 'European'.  And in Germany, the backlash against East Germans is growing.  
It is very similar to the Latin workers in America, except the most countries in Europe do not have the explicit ant-discrimination laws that are in force in the US.
Be careful when painting with a broad brush.  The situation in the US is not perfect, but at least we talk about it.

question_title: Does accepting God require a leap of faith? [SEP] question_content: I've been struggling with this issue for years now. It seems to me that blind acceptance of God only cheapens the spiritual relationship because it removes independent thought from the process. However, taking a leap of faith and accepting God without really believing is equally disingenuous. I want to have more faith, but I don't know how to get there.

PS: I'm not interested in being talked out of religion, my athiest family tried that for 30 years and I doubt there's an angle I haven't heard. [SEP] best_answer: well, faith is all about being able to believe in something without physical proof of it existing. logically, that doesnt make sense. but, thats what faith is about. anyone can have faith in something when its right in front of you with the answers spelled out. but to be realistic, the bible doesnt explain everything. and it contradicts what we know is scientifically proven. but thats just it, you've independantly thought about this, and questioned it, you obviously werent brainwashed into anything. and if you want to believe in it, it sounds like you're ready. if you decide not to, thats cool too. i can understand that.

to me, faith is about saying "i believe theres more to existence than what we understand right now".

question_title: God Threatening to Kill Over Foreskin? [SEP] question_content: Exodus4:23 And I say unto thee, Let my son go, that he may serve me: and if thou refuse to let him go, behold, I will slay thy son, even thy firstborn.   
"If thou refuse to let him go, behold, I will slay thy son, even thy firstborn."
God threatens to kill Pharaoh's firstborn son.  
4:24 And it came to pass by the way in the inn, that the LORD met him, and sought to kill him.    
"The LORD met him, and sought to kill him."
God tries to kill Moses  
4:25 Then Zipporah took a sharp stone, and cut off the foreskin of her son, and cast it at his feet, and said, Surely a bloody husband art thou to me.  
"A bloody husband art thou to me."
God decides to kill Moses because his son had not yet been circumcised. Luckily for Moses, his Egyptian wife Zipporah "took a sharp stone, and cut off the foreskin of her son, and cast it at his feet, and said, Surely a bloody husband art thou to me. [SEP] best_answer: In Judaism, circumcision represents the covenant between YHVH and Abraham.  Moses, in not circumcising his son, was reneging on the covenant.

question_title: What is the difference between Evangelical Christians and standard Christians? I was told they are different.? But I would like more details about what exactly is the difference. [SEP] best_answer: "Traditional" christians are usually quieter in expressing their faith....they are less outspoken, and just live their lives according to their beliefs. They do not tend to "share" their faith. This does not mean they are less devoted than "evangelical" christians who are more expressive, and who do believe in sharing the faith with others. Both can be equally devout, and believe in the same doctrines, but just express in different ways. Cults are typically complete deviations from accepted doctrines.

question_title: Has anyone heard of a band called, "The Walkmen"? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: The Walkmen are an indie rock band from New York City. The band formed with three members from Jonathan Fire Eater which had recently disbanded and two members from The Recoys in 2000. The group comprises of Hamilton Leithauser (vocals, guitar), Paul Maroon (guitar, piano), Walter Martin (organ), Peter Bauer (bass) and Matt Barrick (drums). Their sound is made unique with the use of vintage musical instruments, most famously the clangy upright piano, and through the use of their self-designed recording studio Marcata Recording, which uses analog recording equipment.

The 2002 debut album Everyone Who Pretended to Like Me Is Gone was well received by critics for its experimental approach and progressive sound. The track "We've Been Had" from Everyone Who Pretended... was used on a television commercial for the Saturn Ion. The follow up album Bows and Arrows, was released in 2004 and was listed by many critics as one of the year's best albums while embracing a less whimsical, experimental sound than the previous album. Several songs were featured on the Fox television program The O.C., including "What's in It for Me?", "The Rat" and "Little House of Savages".

Bows and Arrows was released on the Record Collection label from Warner Bros, in contrast to the independent label Startime that released Everyone Who Pretended to Like Me Is Gone.

Their next album, A Hundred Miles Off, will be released in the US on May 23rd. The band premiered most of the new songs on a tour of the Northeast in early 2006. Confirmed song titles for the upcoming album include "Good for You's Good for Me," "All Hands and the Cook," "Lost in Boston," and "This Job Is Killing Me."

2006 may also see the release of another full-length offering by the Walkmen: a re-recording of Harry Nilsson and John Lennon's drug-fueled Pussy Cats album from 1974.

question_title: Only for Beatles' connoisseurs; who can "Boob" be? [SEP] question_content: I recently bought a strange Russian CD called "The Alternate Yellow Submarine" which has some strange and previously unreleased versions, not only from Yellow Submarine album. There is one very strange version of "Lucy in the Sky with Diamonds" which starts being sung in a very weird voice. All the information the CD provides about it is " Unreleased version, first verse is sung by Boob, different lyrics".
 I'll appreciate serious answers, thank you. [SEP] best_answer: The Alternate Yellow Submarine is most likely a direct clone of a album of the same title that was published by a company called Pear. As you probably know already, it is a bootleg with unofficial recordings. As is often the case with Pear (and thus all direct clones), the material they offer is not of the best available quality. But we take what we get... 

Anyway, as for the Lucy in the Sky you speak of, it is RM20, i.e. a mono mix of take 20. It is indeed an alternate take that was to be used in the Yellow Submarine motion picture, nevertheless, it was never used. The first verse was supposed to be sung by the character Nowhere Man (or, as they call him, Boob) from the film (the blue-greyish little creature, remember?) and hence, the hilarious voice with the manic laugh. One of my favourite outtakes, to be quite honest. It's a shame it was left off the Anthology. 

Anywho, hope this helped a bit.

question_title: Where can I get a copy of the theme and bumper musics from Whoopi Goldberg's early-nineties talk show? [SEP] question_content: For about a year in the early 1990's, Whoopi Goldberg had her own half-hour talk show for about a season.  The show never had a studio audience, and it always focused on a single guest for each half-hour.

The opening and bumper musics were these jazzy numbers, and I believe the credits said that they were created by Robbie Robertson.  However, I have yet to find copies of these pieces anywhere, and even the die-hard Whoopi Goldberg fans I've contacted have no idea what the pieces were titled, or where to get copies of them.

Ideally I'd like to buy a CD with the pieces on them, but if the mp3s are out there and they're the only way to get copies of the music, I'll take what I can get. [SEP] best_answer: Contact the studio where the show was filmed..

question_title: Another Simple Riddle? [SEP] question_content: Picture an empty wine bottle with a cork secured at the top in the usual way. Inside the bottle a metal ring hangs suspended by a string. How is it possible to make the metal ring drop to the bottom of the bottle without touching the ring, the thread, the cork, or the bottle while leaving the cork in place and intact? [SEP] best_answer: To burn the string which can be done with a magnifying glass held under the rays of the sun which will cause the string to burn and thus the ring will drop to the bottom of the bottle.

question_title: What is the best thing to do on a snow day? [SEP] question_content: Keep in mind that I don't have a car and I'm in Tennessee. [SEP] best_answer: Wrap up well and keep warm then embrace it head on? go outside do some work; leave out feed for the birds, take the dog for a walk, get involved with the day and make use of it, don't let it weigh you down with gloom and doom type thinking.\nA Snow day is as wonderful on this planet as a Sunny day both have their hidden beauty, or at least is's not at first ovbious, so take a better deeper longer and good look at a snow day, and get involved with it.

question_title: Am I the only one on Earth that hates the ******' Eagles? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: OH GOSH!!!! I knew you were a kindred spirit!\nI have hated the Eagles for years, ever since they did that gayarse publicity stunt with Alistair Crowley hangin out the window of the hotel Cali album, and everyone was like,"ooooh the Eagles, dark mysterious knights of rock n roll", and i was like,"okay, these are dorks playing kicker music with a bit of rock licks thrown in." You kick arrse badkarma!!!!

question_title: V For Vedetta Question!!!!!!!? [SEP] question_content: In The movie "V for Vendetta" is the 5th of November real or did just something important in history happen on this day if so what happened???


Thanks!*!* [SEP] best_answer: It is an actual event that is celebrated in the UK and some of its colonies as Guy Fawkes night.
It celebrates the failure of the gunpowder plot. (so it's real)

The whole rhyme might help you:
    Remember, remember the fifth of November,
    The Gunpowder, Treason and Plot.
    I know of no reason why the gunpowder treason
    should ever be forgot. 
    
Guy Fawkes, Guy Fawkes, 'twas his intent
    to blow up the King and Parliament.
    Three score barrels of powder below,
    to prove old England's overthrow: 

    By God's mercy he was catch'd
    With a dark lantern and burning match.
    Holloa boys, holloa boys, let the bells ring.
    Holloa boys, holloa boys, God save the King!
    Hip hip hoorah! 

    A penny loaf to feed the Pope.
    A farthing o' cheese to choke him.
    A pint of beer to rinse it down.
    A (group) of sticks to burn him. 

    Burn him in a tub of tar.
    Burn him like a blazing star.
    Burn his body from his head.
    Then we'll say ol' Pope is dead. 

    Hip hip huzzah!
    Hip hip huzzah!

question_title: Kids Comment on Love? [SEP] question_content: Tips on love, from those who should know. All questions were answered by kids, ages 5-10.

WHAT IS THE PROPER AGE TO GET MARRIED?

"Eighty-four, because at that age, you don't have to work anymore, and you can spend all your time loving each other in your bedroom." (Judy, 8)

"Once I'm done with kindergarten, I'm going to find me a wife." (Tom, 5)

WHAT DO MOST PEOPLE DO ON A DATE?

"On the first date, they just tell each other lies, and that usually gets them interested enough to go for a second date." (Mike, 9)

WHEN IS IT OKAY TO KISS SOMEONE?

"You should never kiss a girl unless you have enough bucks to buy her a big ring and her own VCR, 'cause she'll want to have videos of the wedding." (Jim, 10)

"Never kiss in front of other people. It's a big embarrassing thing if anybody sees you. But if nobody sees you, I might be willing to try it with a handsome boy, but just for a few hours." (Kally, 9)

THE GREAT DEBATE: IS IT BETTER TO BE SINGLE OR MARRIED?

"It's better for girls to be single, but not for boys. Boys need somebody to clean up after them." (Lynette, 9)

"It gives me a headache to think about that stuff. I'm just a kid. I don't need that kind of trouble." (Kenny, 7)

CONCERNING WHY LOVE HAPPENS BETWEEN TWO PARTICULAR PEOPLE

"No one is sure why it happens, but I heard it has something to do with how you smell. That's why perfume and deodorant are so popular." (Jan, 9)

"I think you're supposed to get shot with an arrow or something, but the rest of it isn't supposed to be so painful." (Harlen, 8)

ON WHAT FALLING IN LOVE IS LIKE

"Like an avalanche where you have to run for your life." (Roger, 9)

"If falling in love is anything like learning how to spell, I don't want to do it. It takes too long." (Leo, 7)

ON THE ROLE OF GOOD LOOKS IN LOVE

"If you want to be loved by somebody who isn't already in your family, it doesn't hurt to be beautiful." (Jeanne, 8)

"It isn't always just how you look. Look at me. I'm handsome like anything and I haven't got anybody to marry me yet." (Gary, 7)

"Beauty is skin deep. But how rich you are can last a long time." (Christine, 9)

CONCERNING WHY LOVERS OFTEN HOLD HANDS

"They want to make sure their rings don't fall off because they paid good money for them." (Dave, 8)

CONFIDENTIAL OPINIONS ABOUT LOVE

"I'm in favor of love as long as it doesn't happen when 'The Simpsons' is on television." (Anita, 6)

"Love will find you, even if you are trying to hide from it. I have been trying to hide from it since I was five, but the girls keep finding me."(Bobby, 8)

"I'm not rushing into being in love. I'm finding fourth grade hard enough."(Regina, 10)

THE PERSONAL QUALITIES NECESSARY TO BE A GOOD LOVER

"One of you should know how to write a check. Because, even if you have tons of love, there is still going to be a lot of bills."(Ava, 8)

SOME SUREFIRE WAYS TO MAKE A PERSON FALL IN LOVE WITH YOU

"Tell them that you own a whole bunch of candy stores." (Del, 6)

"Don't do things like have smelly, green sneakers. You might get attention, but attention ain't the same thing as love." (Alonzo, 9)

"One way is to take the girl out to eat. Make sure it's something she likes to eat. French fries usually works for me." (Bart, 9)

HOW CAN YOU TELL IF TWO ADULTS EATING DINNER AT A RESTAURANT ARE IN LOVE?

"Just see if the man picks up the check. That's how you can tell if he's in love." (John, 9)

"Lovers will just be staring at each other and their food will get cold. Other people care more about the food." (Brad, 8)

"It's love if they order one of those de [SEP] best_answer: oh I love it!!!  this was great!  put me in an even better mood.. its the last day at the office for the week!!! and tomorrow is Thanksgiving!!! food, family, laughs, and relaxing!!! 

Happy Turkey day everyone!!!

question_title: How can handwarmers be made at home? [SEP] question_content: There are handwarmers for sale at places like walmart during the winter months that advertise being made entirely of natural compounds. They heat up to about 120F average and last for around 6 hours. How would someone go about making this at home so as to create something like a shoe insert that heats up? [SEP] best_answer: You could fill a sock with rice or buckwheat, heat it in the microwave for 90 seconds or so and it should provide nice heat for one to two hours.  It's not a chemical handwarmer if that's what you wanted, but it would work. You could react muriatic acid (available in hardware stores) with lye (some oven cleaners) and it would warm up, but I wouldn't recommend it, as you're dealing with HCl and NaOH, both caustic chemicals that will burn you if not careful.  But when they are mixed, it is a pretty exothermic reaction, but not really nontoxic per se.

question_title: Wat happens inside SCR when it goes frm forward block 2 on state,wat is d physics behind this? [SEP] question_content: I want actually to know how depletion regions r being affected because of d regenerative process of increasin alphas that leads to d increase in anode current and this process continues to happen until thyristor is driven to the on state. [SEP] best_answer: I have been taught by my old-timer physics teacher that an SCR is a diode with an insulating space between the P and N layers.  This insulating space is the gate.  An electric field exists when no voltage is applied to the gate, keeping the forward-biased diode from conducting.  But a small current injected into the gate breaks down the field keeping the diode off.  An avalanche between the P and N junctions then commences and the SCR is ON.  The feild cannot reestablish itself until the SCR is REVERSE biased and the gate current is brought to Zero.

question_title: It is true everything about the number PHI ??? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Yes. Phi, 1.618, is the golden number. It is the ratio of two lengths such that the ratio between the longer and the shorter length is the same as the ratio between the whole and the longer length.

If a rectangle is constructed with these ratio's, it can be iteratively subdivided into smaller and smaller golden rectangles, forming an arithmetic spiral. This spiral, when copied and rotated 180 degrees, is the shape that all spiral galaxies take.

Phi is related to the fibonacci sequence. 99% of sunflowers have a fibonnoci number of seeds arranged in this spiral shape.

Phi is approximately the ratio between the lengths of one bone in the finger and the next.

The list goes on... too tired right now to remember more

Edit - holy crap, I didn't know that about the bees. Mind so blown right now.

Also Edit - Gardener's book deals mostly with very loose claims that certain peices of ancient archetecture incorporates knowledge of the number Phi. His points are well thought out and thorough, and have discredited many specious claims about Phi's use in this area. However, the physical manifestations of Phi are very real and undeniable.

question_title: what is the meaning of remote sensing? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: This is a fascinating subject that is rarely discussed.  I have read supposedly legitimate reports that both the United States and the Soviet Union have employed people with so-called "remote sensing" capabilities to locate distant people and places.

For example, the government is looking for a new chemical factory.  One program I saw showed a dramatization in which the "remote seers" were put in a room, and hour by hour they would come closer and closer to pinpointing the exact location of what was being sought.

Double blind tests were done, and if the reports are true, remote sensing is a legitimate psychic phenomena.  When the remote seers located the desired person or object, the amount of detail provided by them was amazing.  These psychics claim the ability to actually see in their mind's eye the object of the search.  They produced drawings, sometimes showing very concrete details that could not be racked up to coincidence.

question_title: pls help me in solving for : integral Arcsin(x) / x^2 dx? [SEP] question_content: is it solved by substituting or by parts? 
[Arcsin(x) mean sin inverse of ( x) ] [SEP] best_answer: I believe Integration by Parts would be your best bet here, since (a) it's straightforward to differentiate Arcsin(x), and (b) it's not hard to integrate x^(-2).

Let u = Arcsin(x) and let dv = x^(-2) dx
Thus du = 1/sqrt(1-x^2) dx and v = -1/x

Set up the IBP formula:

 Int [Arcsin(x)/x^2 dx] = uv - Int [v du]
  =  Arcsin(x)/x - Int [-1/(x sqrt(1-x^2)) dx]
  = Arcsin(x)/x + Int [ x^(-1) (1-x^2)^(-1/2) dx]
... (by substitution*)
  =  Arcsin(x)/x + ln(x) - ln (sqrt (1-x^2) + 1)

Be SURE to visit the Integrator at Wolfram.com (see link below)!

* See also worked-out example #6 at:
http://mathforum.org/mathtools/cell/c,15.14.6,ALL,ALL/

question_title: was 1978 a leap year ? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Agreeing with everyone else, 

No.....1976 and 1980 were.

Keep in mind that Leap Years are always end in even numbers and they do come every 4 years. 

Another way to remember them is if you are a citizen of the United States, all Presidential elections are held in Leap years....I don't know if that was planned but it just happens to be.  

Also all SUMMER Olympics are held during Leap years...The Winter ones used to be held with them but that has changed.  Winter Olympics now follow 2 years after the Summer ones.

Another way to remember is that if you are a fan of Chinese Astrology, each Leap Year is either the sign of the Rat, Dragon or the Monkey.

I know because I was born in a Leap Year......

:)
Peace!

question_title: name the non-metal which is a good conducter of electricity? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: The answer you are probably looking for is graphite, which is an allotrope of carbon. Just "Carbon" isn't a good answer because in the form of diamond or buckyballs carbon is almost completely non-conductive.

Similarly water isn't a good answer since water is a pretty good insulator. Only by dissolving metals such as sodium in the water can you make it conductive.

Having said that there are any number of other non-metallic conductors, but graphite carbon is probably the answer the teacher wants.

question_title: Find an exponential function of the form f(x)=ba^x+c with y interecept 2, horizontal asymptote y=2? [SEP] question_content: here's the rest of the question:
-that passes through the point P(1,4) [SEP] best_answer: f(x) = ba^x + c
Since it passes through the point P(1,4)
f(1) = ba + c = 4
Since the y-intercept is 2 (ie it passes through (0, 2)
f(0) = b + a = 2
The statement "horizontal asymptote y=2" renders a solution impossible. I think you meant horizontal asymptote y=1
Then lim x→-∞  f(x) = c → c = 1
So b + 1 = 2 → b = 1
ba + c = 4 → a = 3

Thus f(x) = 3*x + 1

question_title: The deposition of sediments along the banks of a river is referred to as? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: That would be a natural levee.

When the river's water exceeds its banks, the water begins to slow down.

The slower velocity will cause the heaviest of the sediments to "fall out".

Some of the sediment will be deposited on the banks of the river forming a natural levee.

question_title: how is it that living things(ie. clams and penguins) have been carbon-dated as being thousands of years old? [SEP] question_content: i have heard these examples used in arguments contesting the accuracy of carbon-14 dating. if this dating method is truly inaccutate then why are we teaching it to our children? [SEP] best_answer: Carbon dating works because carbon decays at a constant speed (half life) and it is a very important science for our kids to learn. Any radioactive element in the world decays under this principle, Plutonium etc.

The way it works is that every living being, clam or human is made of carbon and generates it through life. When we die, our production stops. This creates an accurate start point. If we are found in 4006, scientists knowing the half life of C-14 and the carbon present in our body, can calculate that our body is 'roughly' 2000 years old. That is as accurate as archilogists need to be.

So, accuracy is relative. Believe it or not, when an archiologists states that a 'clam' is 5,000 years old plus or minus 200 years, this is considered extremely accurate. Are you saying that clams and penguins were not around thousands of years ago? :)

Hope this helps.

question_title: Is a Sable an antelope ? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: The Sable Antelope (Hippotragus niger) is an antelope that inhabits wooded savannah in East Africa south of Kenya, and in Southern Africa. There are two subspecies: H. n. niger which is considered low risk conservation dependent and the Giant Sable Antelope (H. n. varani) of central Angola which is classified as critically endangered.

The Sable Antelope stands 120 to 140 centimetres at the shoulder and weigh 200 to 270 kilograms, males being larger than females. Female Sable Antelope are chestnut to dark brown darkening as they mature while males are very distinctively black. Both sexes have a white underbelly, white cheeks and a white chin. They have a shaggy mane on the back of their neck. Sable antelope have ringed horns which arch backward, in females these can reach a meter, but in males they can reach over one and a half meters.

Sable Antelope live in wooded savannah where they eat mid-length grass and leaves. They are diurnal but are less active during the heat of the day. Sable Antelope form herds of ten to thirty females and calves led by a single male. Sable Antelope males will fight among themselves; they drop to their knees and use their horns.

The sable antelope was one of the national emblems of Rhodesia (now Zimbabwe).

The sable antelope was also introduced into Texas as game in private ranches

question_title: answer this...plz? [SEP] question_content: A train of 150m length is going towards North at a speed of 10m/s.A bird is flying at 5m/s parallel to the track towards south.The time taken by the bird to cross the train is?plz explain it with whole process. [SEP] best_answer: 10  seconds.

first  you find the relative speed.
since the two are headed toward each other you add their respective speeds  
                   vr = v1+v2 = 10+5= 15 meters/second 

now  you want to find the time it takes to cross 150 meters of the trains length  at this speed 
                          speed =distance/time
                          time = distance /speed =  150/15= 10seconds

question_title: why are sharks such fast swimmers? (no stupid answers/people please.)? [SEP] question_content: its for my homework. lol. [SEP] best_answer: The answer is a combination of several factors.

The skin is designed so as to limit "wrinkling" while swimming. (hydrodynamics) If u look at the skin closely, they consist of placoid scales which r smooth in one direction (swimming direction), and rough in the other direction.

Sharks r seriously buffed up, which aids in generating work.

Fins stabilise the body to prevent it from swimming upside down or in a circle

They belong to the chondrichthyes... cartilaginous fishes. This skeletal system is lighter than boney frames and allows for greater flexibility. Both characteristics COULD help in swimming. (There r, however, many fast marine animals with boney frames such as the dolphin or swordfish).

The tail is the main propulsion force. Which works in coordination with it's respiratory and circulatory system. As water passes over the gills, the lamellae r oxygenated, and at the same time release waste products (co2). So, if the shark swims slowly, the respiration rate decreases... and if he doesn't swim at all, he suffocates. I guess sharks swim fast because they have to. Haha. I hope that's helpful.

question_title: What is an equation with a negative solution that would require your adding 2 negative and 2 positives? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: So long as the absolute value of the sum total of the 2 negative numbers is greater than the absolute value of the sum of the 2 positive numbers the answer should be negative.

Example:
    (-4)+(-3)+(+2)+(+1)=(-4)
Absolute value of (-4)+(-3)= |7|
Absolute value of (+2)+(+1)=|3|
7>3 and 7 is negative so the answer is -4

question_title: Where are Precambrian rocks most likely to be exposed at the surface? [SEP] question_content: IT is from Historical Geology [SEP] best_answer: There are some famous places where Precambrian rock is exposed such as the Canadian Shield. It spans across Canada & parts of Greenland.

The basement rock in the Grand Canyon (rock on the bottom) is also visible.

Most Precambrian rock is covered w/ sediment & or sedimentary rock where lowlying areas of it exist.

Anywhere where Precambrian rock has been uplifted is a good place to look. Like the Teton Mtn. Range in Wyoming. That would be your best bet. At the feet of fault block mtn. ranges.

question_title: Cloudy fish tank? [SEP] question_content: I have two goldfish and an algea eater in a 30 gallon tank.  After 3 years the water has turned cloudy and no matter what I do it stays cloudy.  Up until a few weeks ago it was always crystal clear. [SEP] best_answer: I recommend getting a suction tube to clean out the rocks. These are inexpensive plastic tubes that you can use to remove sediment from the rocks. Remove as much sediment as you want, while trying to avoid disturbing the rest of the tank, or stir up sediment into the water.

Also, I recommend a weekly 10% water change. Make sure that the new water is the same temperature and hardness as the existing water.

Since your tank's water is overly dirty, you may want to perform additional water changes. However, changing too high a % of water at one time can be detrimental to the fishs' health. Perhaps 10% daily water changes can be recommended at the most.

question_title: where do tears came from and how are they made? [SEP] question_content: i know they came from eyes but is it from the front back underneith [SEP] best_answer: Tears partly come from a gland that is located above your eyeball and towards your ear in each eye.  It is called the lacrimal gland.  This gland creates the water part of your tears.  It is this gland that gets activated when something irritates your eye or when you are emotionally "revved up" enough to start crying.  It is simply a system of nerves connected to the gland that cause it to start forming tears.  \n\nThere is what is called a tear film that is constantly covering your eye.  The film is not just made of water - oil and mucus are also part of the tear film.  The mucus' job is to keep the water "stuck" to the front of your eye, and the oil's job is to keep the water from evaporating off of your eye.  When people's eyes start to water excessively, the eye is only creating an excess of the watery part of that tear layer, as explained above.  Hope this helps!

question_title: imaginery numbers? [SEP] question_content: i need to solve the following equater in IMAGINERY numbers:

abs(z)+i*z+i*[attached(z+1)]=sqrt(5)+z+4*i-2

the functions are:
abs  = absolute of an integer
attached = im not sure if this is the correct expression in english, i just verbally translated it from my language, it basically means an imaginery number that if we multiply it with the original imaginery number z, we will get a real number. f.e: 
if z=x+yi then

thus, (x+yi)(x-yi)= x^2+y^2.

the solution according to the guy that wrote this book is:

i got a very ugly solution and i tried this damn equator for about a million times. its supposed to be rather easy.

the only thing i wasnt sure about is if the attached imaginery number of ((x+y*i)+1) is (x+1-y*i) while (z=x+y*i)

thanks ahead. [SEP] best_answer: In your equation
abs(z)+i*z+i*[attached(z+1)]=s...
The R.H.S =s... ? what is that mean ?
Attached =Conjugate
The conjugate of ((x+y*i)+1) is (x+1-y*i) while (z=x+y*i)
As you think
Give me the value of s and I'll solve you the problem
Thanks
After you gave me the R.H.S
Let z= x + iy
Then your equation Will be:
L.H.S = sqrt(x^2+y^2)+ i*(x + iy)+ i*(x - iy +1) 
      = (sqrt(x^2+y^2 -y +y ) + i *( x+x+1)
      = (sqrt(x^2+y^2) = i *(2x + 1)
R.H.S = (sqrt(5) + x - x ) + i *(y + 4)
Equating the real and imaginary parts
  2x +1 = y +4
      y = 2x -3             (1)
and : sqrt(x^2 + y^2) = sqrt(5)
so          x^2 + y^2 = 5   (2)
substituting from (1) in (2)
  x^2 + (2x -3 )^2 =5
so  5 x^2 - 12 x + 4 =0
which gives x=2   then y =1 then z = 2 + i
or x = 2/5  y = -11/3    then z = 2/5 - 11/5 i

question_title: how scientists get power from atoms? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: By power, i assume you mean "energy over time"
When an atom such as uranium is 'split' by bombarding the nucleus with high energy neutrons, it forms two nuclei with lower masses than the uranium. There is, however, a mass defect - a "missing mass" that gives rise to an energy output via
E = mc^2
By harnessing this energy, scientists can use it to generate electricity, a bit like in a regular coal-fired power station.

According to the theory, this collapse of the universe will continue until the universe has lost all its mass and turned into a single point of infinite density.\nScientists believe the creation of the universe began with a huge explosion. From this point, the universe has been expanding ever since. Scientists say that when the mass of the universe has reached a sufficient level, this expansion will come to an end because of gravity, causing the universe to collapse in on itself. \nIt is also believed that the contracting universe will end in a fierce heat and contraction known as the "Big Crunch." This would lead to the end of all forms of life as we know them. question_title: what is a mosfet(electronic component) n what it does? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Metal Oxide Semiconductor Field Effect Transistor.  It's the basic component of most electronic circuits and all digital ones.  It's the breakthrough that made computers so cheap, small and popular.  A transistor, you know, acts as an electrical "gate," acting on a smaller input voltage to allow a larger voltage to pass through.  So a transistor can act as an amplifier, by using a smaller current to control a larger current.  Used in a circuit called a "flip-flop," it makes up the basic circuit for computers and other digital electronics.\n\nThere are many kinds of transistors, dating all the way back to vacuum tubes; the reason MOSFETs are such a big deal is because they are made by "printing," in huge quantities and on extremely small scales, directly onto microchips.

question_title: how do sponges carry out essientail fuctions? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Within a sponge, there is an intriguing body structure. While the sponge functions as a unified organism, each cell is a division of its own mini-organism. Essentially, a sponge is a combination of billions of cells that function together. Within the body of the sponge, several processes occur which are vital to its welfare. Most importantly, sponges conduct the processes of respiration, digestion, protection, development, and reproduction. 

All of these processes are generated by the consistent filtration of the water encompassing it. Through an intricate system of incurrent and afferent ducts, it processes food, oxygen, and other useful materials. The exterior layer of skin is covered in pinacocytes, which open the afferent ducts. In addition, the afferent ducts allow water to be transferred through the porocytes. The functions of the afferent ducts are regulated by the myocytes, muscular cells that permit them to open and close. After this the water travels through the incurrent ducts. 

Within the system of incurrent ducts, water is processed for useful materials. The interior layer of tissue forces the water through the ostioles into chambers lined with choanae and flagellates. Eventually, water is directed towards the atrial cavity. After the water is processed through the atrial cavity and removed of a sufficient amount of oxygen, it is released through the osculum. The osculum is a relatively maximized opening in the body of the sponge. At this point in filtration, waste water will be ejected.

At some point after life first appeared on Earth, an accidental mutation in some organism caused certain nerve endings to become light sensitive. This new trait increased the survival probability for this species which means it produced more copies of itself than other species without the mutation. Over a very long period of time, this first primitive "eye" mutated even more, gradually evolving into the modern eye.

In the wild large adults tend to weigh around 70kg (154 pounds). Captive specimens often weigh more. The largest verified specimen was 3.13 metres (10 feet 3 inches) long and weighed 166kg (365 pounds), including undigested food. [1] It is a member of the monitor lizard family, Varanidae, and inhabits various islands in Indonesia. The Papua monitor, Varanus salvadorii may surpass the Komodo in length but it is slimmer and weighs less.

question_title: The various factors that influence the biomechanical behaviour of bone in vivo? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: 1. Calcium, phosphate, and vit. D levels
2. Wolff's law - increased mechanical stress on bone causes increased bone deposit
3. Hormonal levels - e.g. low estrogen levels may cause osteoporosis
4. Activity level - sedentary vs. active
5. Disease or not - e.g. some tumors are osteolytic, osteogenesis imperfecta, infection

question_title: Find the quotient and remainder using synthetic division? [SEP] question_content: (x^4+x^3-2x^2-3x-1)/(x-2) [SEP] best_answer: 2|1 1 -2 -3 -1
..... 2 6 ..8 10
----------------
...1 3 4 ..5 9

So the quotient is x³ + 3x² + 4x + 5, and the remainder is 9

question_title: why respiratory alkalosis do not occur in children in cases of aspirin poisoning? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: I'm an MD...
ACUTE aspirin overdose causes acid-base imbalance in two ways.  To understand this, you need to have a basic understanding of acidosis/alkilosis in the body.  (skip this if you allready know it!)
I'll keep it simple - there are two places in the body that affect your acid-base balance, your kidneys and your lungs.  
Your kidney can increase/decrease the amount of bicarbonate (a natural base) produced or reabsorbed over the course of hours-days.  When this goes haywire, its called a METABOLIC acidosis (decreased bicarb) or alkilosis (increased bicarb).
Your lungs can increase/decrease the amount of carbon dioxide (a natural acid when dissolved) that you get rid of in ventilation.  By increasing or decreasing your breathing rate, you therefor adjust your body's pH in a matter of minutes.  When this goes haywire, its called a RESPIRATORY acidosis (decreased or hypo-ventilation) or alkilosis (increased or hyper-ventilation).
When either of these two goes wrong, the body tries to use the other to compensate.  So when you have kidney failure, causing a primary metabolic acidosis, the respiratory center  in the medulla makes you HYPOventilate to breath off less CO2 to help compensate.  This compensation is fast over a matter of minutes.  Vice versa can also occur when the kidney compensate for the lungs, but this takes longer, of a matter of hours-days.

OK! Back to aspirin.  Aspirin is unique for a couple reasons.  First of all it has an entirely different effect if it is one large acute overdose vs a chronicly high level.  Secondly, in an acute overdose, aspirin causes an acidosis by TWO mechanisms - a primary metabolic AND primary respiratory acidosis.  How?  Aspirin causes metabolic acidosis and simultaneously inhibites the medulla's respiratory drive center causing respiratory acidosis.  This is seen in adults as well as children.  Children should use tylenol instead of aspirin, however, due to its loose association with a terrible desease known as Reye's Sydrome.

BOTTOM LINE - Aspirin blocks compensatory respiratory alkalosis in children and adults by suppressing our medullary respiratory drive center.

Acute Aspirin Toxicity:
    * Uncompensated Respiratory Acidosis
    * Cause: Huge amout of Aspirin causes medullary inhibition --> Hypoventilaion --> increase of Serum CO2 --> respiratory acidosis
    * Moreover, the kidneys are normally excreting bicarbonate products (alkali in nature) --> more acidosis (metabolic now).
    * This leads to severe uncompensated acidosis

Chronic Aspirin Toxicity:
    * Compensated Respiratory Alkalosis
    * Cause: Mild accumulation of Aspirin over time causes medullary stimulation > hyperpnea --> excretion of more CO2 --> decrease of Serum CO2 --> respiratory alkalosis
    * However, the kidneys are normally excreting bicarbonate products (alkali in nature) --> neutralization of the present alkalosis (compensation) --> pH back to normal

Hope this helps.........

question_title: y=(x^5-3x^3)cos(2+3x-5x^7) --- Derivative? [SEP] question_content: A little confused on this one. [SEP] best_answer: It's a product:

if f(x) = a*b
then f'(x) = a*(b') + b*(a')

Also, you must multiply by the derivative of "what's inside."  For this problem, you must take the derivative of "what's inside" the cosine parentheses (2 + 3x - 5x^7).

So for this one, a = x^5 - 3x^3 and b = cos(2 + 3x - 5x^7).  "What's inside" is (2 + 3x - 5x^7).  Therefore:

--- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- --- ---- ---- --- "what's inside"
f'(x) = ( (x^5 - 3x^3)(-sin(2 + 3x - 5x^7)*(3 - 35x^6)) + (cos(2 + 3x - 5x^7)*(5x^4 - 9x^2))

question_title: Find the volume, to the nearest tenth, of a pyramid that is 6 feet  tall and whose base is? [SEP] question_content: an equilateral triangle with sides each 10 feet long? [SEP] best_answer: The area of the equilateral triangle is:

A = 0.433 s^2

A = 0.433 (10 ft)^2

A = 43.3 ft^2

The volume of the pyramid is:

V = 1/3 A h

V = 1/3 (43.3 ft^2) (6 ft)

V = 86.6 ft^3

question_title: whats the energy sounces ex:hydroeletric,sloar,and the fossil fuel, ect !? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Hydroelectric: moving water from natural or artificial waterfalls powers turbines.

Solar: Special reflective surfaces called photovoltaic convert the sun's radiation into energy, used to power turbines.

Wind:  Large turbines are pushed by the movement of the winds; resemble giant windmills.

Oil, Natural Gas & Coal (fossil fuels):  Are extracted and burned to power generator turbines.

Nuclear (fission): The power of the atom is harnessed as atoms are split apart and the resultant energy used to power turbines; buildings marked by iconic hour-glass-shaped cooling towers.

Biomass: The buring of biologic materials to power turbines.

Waste-to-Energy: the burning of waste materials (such as trash) to power turbines.

Nuclear (fussion): Still being developed; fusing atomic nuclei together and capturing the resultant release of energy.

question_title: Cyclinders? [SEP] question_content: If you have a cylinder and you double the radius how does this change the Volume and surface area? [SEP] best_answer: The volume of a cylinder is found by using the formula:
[pi]*hr^2
If I were to double the radius, then I would have:
[pi]*h*(2r)^2 = 4*[pi]*hr^2
So doubling the radius will make the volume four times as much.

The surface area of a cylinder is found using the formula:
(2*[pi]*r^2) + (2*[pi]*hr)
If I double the radius, then I will have:
(2*[pi]*(2r)^2) + (2*[pi]*h(2r))
= (8*[pi]*r^2) + (4*[pi]*hr)
If we factor out a 2, then we have:
2 * {(4*[pi]*r^2) + (2*[pi]*hr)}
Which is more than double the original.  In fact, it doubles the original volume, then adds the surface area of original ends (circles) again.

question_title: what is the principle of the barometer and how it works? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: There are several way in which a barometer work.  The most common is a needle attached to a spring and a tensioning device which expands and contracts based upon the amount of atmospheric pressure it is exposed to.  \nThe second type is what is called Galileo's barometer.  Globes are filled with a number of\nliquids of different specific gravities (this is the density of the liquid with respect to the density of water).  As the air pressure changes, these different globes will either float or sink based upon the changes in air pressure.   The third type is the electronic barometer.  It uses a pressure transducer, which causes changes in electric current bases upon changes in air pressure.  These changes are converted into either an analog (needle meter) or digital display of the value of the air pressure.

question_title: What causes the "rainbow" to have an arc,to it? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: What makes the bow?
A question like this calls for a proper physical answer. We will discuss the formation of a rainbow by raindrops. It is a problem in optics that was first clearly discussed by Rene Descartes in 1637. An interesting historical account of this is to be found in Carl Boyer's book, The Rainbow From Myth to Mathematics. Descartes simplified the study of the rainbow by reducing it to a study of one water droplet and how it interacts with light falling upon it. 
He writes:"Considering that this bow appears not only in the sky, but also in the air near us, whenever there are drops of water illuminated by the sun, as we can see in certain fountains, I readily decided that it arose only from the way in which the rays of light act on these drops and pass from them to our eyes. Further, knowing that the drops are round, as has been formerly proved, and seeing that whether they are larger or smaller, the appearance of the bow is not changed in any way, I had the idea of making a very large one, so that I could examine it better. 

Descarte describes how he held up a large sphere in the sunlight and looked at the sunlight reflected in it. He wrote "I found that if the sunlight came, for example, from the part of the sky which is marked AFZ  

and my eye was at the point E, when I put the globe in position BCD, its part D appeared all red, and much more brilliant than the rest of it; and that whether I approached it or receded from it, or put it on my right or my left, or even turned it round about my head, provided that the line DE always made an angle of about forty-two degrees with the line EM, which we are to think of as drawn from the center of the sun to the eye, the part D appeared always similarly red; but that as soon as I made this angle DEM even a little larger, the red color disappeared; and if I made the angle a little smaller, the color did not disappear all at once, but divided itself first as if into two parts, less brilliant, and in which I could see yellow, blue, and other colors ... When I examined more particularly, in the globe BCD, what it was which made the part D appear red, I found that it was the rays of the sun which, coming from A to B, bend on entering the water at the point B, and to pass to C, where they are reflected to D, and bending there again as they pass out of the water, proceed to the point ". 

This quotation illustrates how the shape of the rainbow is explained. To simplify the analysis, consider the path of a ray of monochromatic light through a single spherical raindrop. Imagine how light is refracted as it enters the raindrop, then how it is reflected by the internal, curved, mirror-like surface of the raindrop, and finally how it is refracted as it emerges from the drop. If we then apply the results for a single raindrop to a whole collection of raindrops in the sky, we can visualize the shape of the bow. 

The traditional diagram to illustrate this is shown here as adapted from Humphreys, Physics of the Air.  It represents the path of one light ray incident on a water droplet from the direction SA. As the light beam enters the surface of the drop at A, it is bent (refracted) a little and strikes the inside wall of the drop at B, where it is reflected back to C. As it emerges from the drop it is refracted (bent) again into the direction CE. The angle D represents a measure of the deviation of the emergent ray from its original direction. Descartes calculated this deviation for a ray of red light to be about 180 - 42 or 138 degrees. 

The ray drawn here is significant because it represents the ray that has the smallest angle of deviation of all the rays incident upon the raindrop. It is called the Descarte or rainbow ray and much of the sunlight as it is refracted and reflected through the raindrop is focused along this ray. Thus the reflected light is diffuse and weaker except near the direction of this rainbow ray. It is this concentration of ray

question_title: What is the explaination for seashells found on the top of a mountain? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: It is quite simple really. There is no 'theory' as some of the posts have indicated. The earth is composed of a number of large plates, which move constantly (the Pacific Ocean today is spreading at 4-5 cm per year). As these plates move, they sometimes slide under one another. As this happens, the upper plate is lifted. This moves rock that was deposited in an ocean environment slowly upwards and often to the top of mountains. The process takes millions of years, so it is likely the rocks that contain the shells on the top of the mountain your husband refers to are tens of millions of years old, or older. 

A perfect example is Mount Everest, which has carbonate rocks (with shells) at the peak. Other examples are many parts of the Rocky Mountains in North America, and the Alps in Europe. The Sierra's in California also contain carbonate rocks in many places that did in fact originate in what is now the Pacific Ocean. It is not rare and not mysterious or theoretical. 

The names of these processes, in case you want to learn more, are plate tectonics (previously called continental drift), subduction (one plate under another), orogeny (mountain building), and carbonate sedimentology( deposition of carbonate rocks).  I'm including some links with basic explanation of the concepts. 

Animated illustrations of plate tectonics:
http://www.ucmp.berkeley.edu/geology/tectonics.html

Illustration of subduction:
http://www.platetectonics.com/book/page_12.asp

Orogeny:
http://www.uwgb.edu/dutchs/platetec/orogeny.htm

Carbonate sedimentology (great pictures of carbonates in mountains (sea shells):http://epswww.unm.edu/sed/home.htm
Other carbonate sedimentology links:
http://www.unige.ch/sciences/terre/geologie/w_groups/carbonate_sedimentology/webmain.html

If you want to see my explanation for how sea shells form in the ocean go to this question:
http://answers.yahoo.com/question/index;_ylt=AiyMjODIRNiCqQ3uGA0_ICPsy6IX?qid=1006011004317

question_title: as secondary growth proceeds in a dicot stem,the thickness of................................................. [SEP] question_content: a)both sapwood and heartwood remains the same
b)both sapwood and heart wood increases
c)heartwood increases
d)sapwood increases [SEP] best_answer: a) is correct.
In vascular plants, secondary growth or, perhaps more accurately, secondary thickening is the result of the activity of the vascular cambium. The latter is a meristem that divides off cells: the cells on the inside of the meristem (the adaxial side) will become secondary xylem, while the cells on the outside (the abaxial side) will become the secondary phloem. This growth increases the girth of the plant, rather than its length, hence the phrase "secondary thickening". As long as the vascular cambium continues to produce new cells, the plant will continue to grow more stout. If this is kept up over many years, this process produces wood.Because this growth ruptures the epidermis of the stem, woody plants also may have a cork cambium that develops among the phloem. The cork cambium gives rise to thickened cork cells to protect the surface of the plant and reduce water loss.

1+1/(2^s)+1/(3^s)+1/(4^s)+ . . . =1+2^(-s)+3^(-s)+4^(-s)+. . .  is greater than or equal to 1+1/2+1/3+1/4+. . . for s less than or equal to 1.

therefore, for s=-2, it would diverge.

Interest in the concept stems from particle theories, notably Grand Unified Theories and superstring theories that predict either the existence or the possibility of magnetic monopoles.

question_title: Why is the weather more cold when there is no cloud cover? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Another individual stated that the clouds act as a blanked and keept the earth warm.  That is an accurate answer. So, let's look a little deeper.

First, clouds are the formations of moisture.  The thicker the clouds, the more moisture that is in them. 

Next, remember that heat rises.  During the day, the earth is warmed.  It cools at night.  The heat rises into the air.

Water has a high specific heat, meaning a large amount of energy is needed to heat the water.  Likewise, it take a long period of time to cool the water.

As the clouds cover the earth, they are insulating the land.  Thus when the heat rises, it hits the clouds creating a barrier.  Thus the rate of cooling is slower than when there is not any cloud cover.

Please note there are exceptions to the rule.  We've all seen or heard of snowstorms coming in and the air is cooling very quickly.  But the general rule is that on a cloudy winter night, the temperature will not drop as low as if there were no clouds.  And you are less likely to scrape frost from your windshield.

question_title: When I click print, nothing happens? [SEP] question_content: I'm using some sort of a Canon printer and the lights on it keep blinking on and off in green. I can't turn it off either because it won't work. When I click print, it goes on the printing queue as "Deleting - Printing" (I dunno if it's normal?) and the document disappears off of the list after a short time..

Help appreciated... Thanks!! [SEP] best_answer: Can you print a demo page from the printer? That is always the best first step in diagnosing a printer problem! If you can, you know the printer will print, so we can move on to the connections.

Ensure your connections are sound. Unplug and reattatch all your cables, including your power cable. (If you can't shut off your Printer using its own power button, that may signal that there is a serious problem with the printer.) OK, once all the cables are back in place, try to print again. NOTHING?

Next, uninstall and reinstall your printer. Ensure that you completly uninstall your printer from your PC, don't just update the drivers. The installed drivers may be corrupt. Also, if you allow windows to reinstall the drivers and the printer continues to have the same issue, you may need to download a new driver from the manufacturers web site. If the windows version of the driver didn't work, uninstall and reinstall using this downloaded driver instead.

If that doesn't work...here is where can get pricey!

First, if you have a friend with a accessable PC, take your printer there, hook it up as you would at home and see what happens. If it has the same issue there, then you have narrowed down the problem to being either the printer or the cable connecting the printer to the PC.

Second step would be to replace the printer cable. (Mind you, this may not be your issue, it could still be the printer and you may waste your money) A good solution is if that same friend uses the same type of cable you do, use that one and see if your printer works. If none of that works, it is time to put that printer out to pasture and buy a new one!

question_title: Multithreaded Swing Applications ? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Swing components are not inherently thread safe, and as a general rule, after Swing components have been made visible on the screen, you can only safely modify their data from the event thread. If you modify Swing component data from any thread other than the event dispatching thread, you must take precautions to ensure data integrity. An exception to this rule is the setText method on a JTextComponent or any of its subclasses, or any Swing component method whose documentation explicitly states it is thread safe. 

Sometimes, you cannot avoid modifying Swing component data from outside the event dispatching thread after it has been made visible. An example is spawning a thread to handle a long operation such as reading or writing a large file over the net. The advantage to spawning a new thread is that the user interface is made available to the user for other operations during the long file operation. The spawned thread is a new thread, and therefore, not on the event dispatching thread even if it is spawned by an event dispatching thread method. 

This article explains how to use the InvokeLater method and synchronize keyword to ensure data integrity when modifying data in Swing components. If you are new to multi-threaded programming, see Creating a Threaded Slide Show Applet for an introduction to the threaded applications. 

For furthur info please visit:
http://java.sun.com/developer/technicalArticles/Threads/swing/

question_title: the purpose of the special keys on the keyboard, and list the most frequently used pointing devices.? [SEP] question_content: the purpose of the special keys on the keyboard, and list the most frequently used pointing devices. [SEP] best_answer: Special keys are either shortcuts to frequently used features or commands of the computer system.
In PC's for instance, the key with the Windows logo opens the "start menu". In a Mac there is the Apple key that brings up the Apple menu. 
Other special keys, such as the Ctrl key, allow for extending the number of commands or instructions available to the user through the keyboarde.g.: pressing at the same time ctrl and "c" whatever text is selected on screen moves to a temporary storage (process called copy) and can be inserted on another text by pressing together ctrl and "v" (called paste).
The most common pointing device is the mouse (for desktop PC), next are the Touchpad (surface where you slide your fingertip to move the cursor) usually for laptops/notebooks and the stylus, a pen-like device that requires a touch-enabled screen or a special pad.

question_title: What is the difference between AGP and PCI graphics cards? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: AGP or Accelerated Graphics Port succeeded PCI or Peripheral Component Interconnect as a technology to connect graphics cards to a computer's motherboard. PCI is still used to connect other devices like ethernet and sound cards.

AGP slots provide a dedicated link between the card and the CPU and thus providing faster communication between them.  There are other enhancements as well.  See the source for more.  But the bottom line is that AGP cards perform much better.

But now AGP is getting phased in favor of PCIe or PCI Express which is even faster and can be used as the bus for all the devices in a machine.

question_title: Moving files from my Hard drive  in my computer to my external hard drive? [SEP] question_content: I am trying to move files from my computer to my external hard drive , which has way more memory, but I can't seem to move Windows , obviously I am new to this .. frustrating ..but I ain't gonna give up   HELP ....IS  THERE A "MAGIC bUTTON THAT I DON'T KNOW ABOUT [SEP] best_answer: If you're moving Windows files it sounds like you're trying to copy everything from your hard drive to the external disk drive (EDD).

This is fine if you're making a back-up of everything but you can't run Windows from your EDD.  You can put your other files on the EDD but Windows needs to run from your computer hard-drive.

On the basis that you're making a back up of everything...

The problem with doing this is that you can't easily copy files that are being used by your computer and with Windows running there will be several files that are in use.

There's a couple of things that you can do.  The first is to get a program that does everything for you.  A good one is Norton Ghost, not only will it make a complete back up but in future it will keep making backups - whenever files change or are added to your computer Ghost will copy them to your EDD, that way you always have a mirror of your computer hard-drive and you can forget about manually backing things up.

The other option is to not have Windows running but this means backing up using XCOPY straight from the command prompt in DOS and if you've got XP then you won't have DOS. In other words, this method works only with older versions of Windows.

There's a couple of articles here that may help - the first uses the DOS approach... http://www.csulb.edu/~murdock/xcopy.html and the second is a technical response... http://www.duxcw.com/digest/Howto/hd/cpyhd/index.html 

Personally, I'd get Norton Ghost - pop it in your CD Drive and let it do all the work for you.  You can download it direct from Symantec... http://www.symantec.com/index.htm

question_title: which is better , ATI Radeon x 1650 or nvidia geforce fx5200? question_title: External Hard Drive? [SEP] question_content: What are the differences in  the two types of external hard drives that are: 7200 rpm or a 2.0 usb.  Is one faster than the other?  More efficient?  tell me what you can.  thanks. [SEP] best_answer: It really doesn't matter much.  Get the best deal you can on a good quality external drive.  Read some reviews and choose something with a warranty of at least 1 year.

USB 2.0 is faster than 1.1, but you won't be able to use it anyway unless your computer has the appropriate motherboard or usb card installed.  And unless you're going to be transferring huge files, the difference in transfer speed won't really be noticeable.

As far as the rpm of the hard drive, that's even less important.

Since an external hard drive is used for achive purposes you should consider the quality of the drive more important than anything else because if it fails, it'll end up being an over-priced paperweight.

question_title: Anyone know why one Gigabyte is 1024MB and not 1000 even? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: Computers run on base-2 arithmetic, since a bit in the computer can only be on or off (positive or negative charge) and thus has only two distinct states.  Since this is true, the amount of memory is also expressed in powers of 2, rather than in decimal (base 10) numbers.

1024 is a power of 2 (2 raised to the 10th power):

2 x 2 = 4 (two of the 2s)
4 x 2 = 8 (#3)
8 x 2 = 16 (#4)
16 x 2 = 32 (#5)
32 x 2 = 64 (#6)
64 x 2 = 128 (#7)
128 x 2 = 256 (#8)
256 x 2 = 512 (#9)
512 x 2 = 1024 (#10)

question_title: reg cleaners/virtual memory/ram/programmes? [SEP] question_content: Hello...I am improving rapidly thanks to your answers...Here are some more.I installed reg cleaner..my computer was full of CRAP...I must have put it there but dont know how...reg cleaner has put it in back up..is this logical ? Do I really need to back up my CRAP ? Is it using memory in back up ?
Ram...I checked my ram..thanks to answers intructions..yes I am low..have ordered 250 from local pc shop.Will there be a point when I have used all my ram and cannot buy any more ?What exactly is it that uses your memory ?Do I waste memory by downloading silly things I dont need then uninstalling them? I thought that when I uninstalled some thing it took it out of memory and I went back to where I was before.
What exactly does it mean when you say "you are running too many programmes at once ? Do you mean at start up?If I take them of start up where do they go ?Can I get them back ?what do you recommend minimum at start up..I only use my computer for fun...Confused OAP but learning fast [SEP] best_answer: I have never used reg cleaner, but I do use ccleaner, which can do similar tasks to reg cleaner ( http://www.ccleaner.com ).  The backup to your reg is simply so, IF something goes wrong after the "cleaning" you can restore your registry values to a time when everything was working ok - and yes the backup file will be using memory up.

IF you download, AND install things (means you have loaded a programme to your computer rather than just downloading a picture file for example), then if you think they are no longer needed you can just uninstall them again.  Go to "CONTROL PANEL" and then to "ADD OR REMOVE PROGRAMS".  Here you can see all the programmes you have installed.  You can remove programmes you don't want by selecting it and then clicking the "REMOVE" button.  But, don't uninstall anything that you're not sure about, as it may be a vital programme!!!

Ok ... the start up programmes .....

If you click START then RUN, and type "msconfig" (without the quotes) and then click OK.  Select the STARTUP tab, and it will show a list of all items which currently load when you start your computer.  Be careful with this, as you don't want to stop something from loading if it is important.

Visit here http://www.sysinfo.org/startupinfo.html as there is a lot of info, AND a list of every start up item with advice on whether to leave it running or not.  But, like I say ... be careful.

I hope this has helped, message me if you want some more help!

question_title: plz tell me the least mebabytes the movie file of 1GB be compressed!!? [SEP] question_content:  [SEP] best_answer: There is no way to answer this question as most modern compression algorithms use tokenization. The extent of tokenization possible is dependent on the data being tokenized. It is POSSIBLE that a handpicked special instance of a 1GB file could be reduced to 50MB or so.\nIt is also important to know what format the movie already is in (wma,mpg,avi,rm) as if it is already compressed further techniques will have minimal effect.

question_title: How do you enter data in an Microsoft Access 2003 version Form in Form View? [SEP] question_content: This is a question which refers to filling in forms and using forms in Form View in the Microsoft Access 2003 software for creating databases instead of using Microsoft Excel. [SEP] best_answer: The form has to be based on an existing table in order for you to be able to enter data.  You should have a table with the various fields (or columns) ready to go.  You can create a form based on that table, and you can pick which fields will be filled in via the form.\n\nForm view simply refers to the form itself, ready to use, as opposed to Design view, where you're setting up the look of the form (i.e. spacing, size of the boxes, etc.).

question_title: difference between 64bit and 128bit video cards? [SEP] question_content: Please tell me the difference between 64bit and 128bit video cards  (like Nvidia) and if each requires a different connection; for example does 64 bit card fit in the same slot as 128 bit? Also is 128 bit better? Thank you, I appreciate your help. [SEP] best_answer: I would think the difference is that a 64bit would have a 64bit GPU and a 128bit would have a 128bit GPU.  The GPU is the graphical processing unit (the video card's own on-board processor), it's what allows video cards to do things like do your 3D graphics so your computer doesn't have to.  The 128bit probably would be better, but it might not be since bit-rate isn't the only factor in speed.
Look at the following things:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graphics_processing_unit
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bit-rate

question_title: where is the reduce red eye button in adobe photoshop cs? [SEP] question_content: I'm trying to reduce red eye in some photo's with Adobe photoshop cs and cant find the button anywhere. can someone point me in the right direction [SEP] best_answer: Photoshop's tool bar contains more than just the buttons you see. By left clicking and holding down the mouse on a tool button that has a small arrow in its corner, a list box appears that gives you more boxes to pick from.\n\nThat is why you don't see the red eye button. It is hidden inside the healing tool button. Position your mouse over the button that looks like button, hold down the left button, and when a popup menu appears, select the red eye removal tool.
